title: In a mixture of 100 liters, milk and water are in ratio 7:3. How much milk should be added to the mixture to bring the ratio of milk and water to 3:1? - Quora

response.answer_text: If they’re in a seven-to-three ratio, then, in every ten parts, seven are milk and three are water. If there are 100 liters in total, then how many sets of ten liters are there? (Hint: Divide.) So how many liters of milk are there? (Hint: Multiply) And how many liters of water are there? (Hint: Multiply by the same value.) You want a ratio of milk to water of three-to-one. That means that, for every one liter of water, you want three liters of milk. Given the amount of water that you already have, how many liters of milk would be equal to three times this amount? (Hint: Multiply by 3) How much milk then should be added? (Hint: Subtract.)
Answer is 20L Amount of milk in 100L mixture=(7/10)*100=70L Amount of water in 100L mixture =(3/10)*100=30L Let the milk to be added be X (70+X)/30=3/1 70+X=90 X=20
